Headline.Para: Fund manager interview series; Emerging market bonds an oasis in a yield desert

LeadPara.Para: Sergei Strigo, head of emerging market debt at Amundi Asset Management, discusses his outlook on emerging markets, fixed bonds and investing opportunities in the latest of our series featuring fund managers and leading market experts.

Mr Sergei Strigo has been heading the emerging market debt team at Amundi Asset Management since 2010, and has more than 17 years of industry experience. He is co-portfolio manager of Amundi Funds - Bond Global Emerging Hard Currency.

TailParas.Para: The fund invests mainly in bonds and convertible bonds of governments and companies in emerging countries which are denominated in euro, Swiss franc, pound, US dollar or yen. The fund also seeks to achieve a combination of income and capital growth, and may appeal to investors who are looking to diversify a portfolio by adding emerging market bond exposure. The fund became available to retail investors in Singapore from March last year.
Amundi had US$775 billion (S$1.02 trillion) of assets under management in fixed income at the end of December last year, making the firm one of the world's largest fixed-income investors.
Q What have been the key drivers of the strong performance in the emerging market bond market? Will this continue?

A We have had a strong run in emerging market bonds, with continued inflows especially in the past few years. Inflows into the asset class in the year to date hit US$100 billion, the highest level in recent history. Furthermore, the past decade had only two years of negative returns - in 2008 and 2013 - for emerging market debt hard currency bonds. Strong macroeconomic fundamentals have been supportive of this trend, with an improved global economy, recovering growth and relatively low unemployment rates.

I believe emerging market bonds offer an attractive story, and will continue to offer an oasis of yield in a yield desert. Based on comparable indexes, emerging market hard currency bonds offer yields of over 5.3 per cent, which are very attractive to investors looking for higher income.
Looking ahead, there are three reasons why emerging market bonds will continue to remain attractive.
GEOPOLITICAL CONCERNS

We are in an age of geopolitical risk, where the biggest sources of risks are external. We have sources of geopolitical tensions emerging which will impact emerging markets, such as the renewed instability in the Middle East and unpredictable international policy strategy towards North Korea.
MR SERGEI STRIGO

First, the growth of emerging market economies has stabilised and shown lower external vulnerabilities. The asset class has shown resilience during periods of market volatility - across the Federal Reserve rate hike cycles, post-election in the United States, Brexit and amid China's growth concerns at the start of 2016.

Second, while strong inflows into emerging market bonds persist, it is still an underinvested asset class, which means there is still room for more gains. Exposure to emerging market debt for global funds is currently less than 10 per cent. This is low compared to the 2008 pre-crisis peak of well over 10 per cent.

Third, there is value to be found in emerging market debt. In Argentina and Brazil for example, we believe bonds are relatively cheap due to country-specific issues as well as global commodity prices stabilising. Political reforms and improvements have also helped the economies and bond market.
Q What opportunities do you see on the horizon in Asia and globally?
A Hard currency bonds are our biggest conviction today. These are bonds denominated in currencies that are widely accepted globally such as US dollar, euro and yen.

When we talk about emerging market debt, we split it into three asset classes. First, hard currency debt, which is mostly in dollars and euros. Second, local currency debt, which are local currency bonds. Third, the currency itself. Of the three, hard currency bonds are the least volatile and most defensive asset class, as it can eliminate currency risk.

Following spread widening last month, hard currency bonds offer more value to investors. However, local currency bonds are also a very attractive asset class for investors looking for potentially higher absolute returns over the next few months.

We are positive on higher yielding assets, particularly Brazil in Latin America and Indonesia in Asia. In addition, we see some interesting opportunities in Asian credit, especially in China, and in local currency and forex space in India, Indonesia and Malaysia.
Q What was your most successful investment strategy last year?

A One of our best was the "bond global emerging hard currency" strategy, which returned 10.7 per cent last year, compared with 8.2 per cent for the strategy's benchmark - the JPMorgan EMBI Global Diversified Index.
The strategy invests primarily in emerging market sovereign debt denominated in US dollar and euro. We have a registered fund based on this strategy here that is available for retail investors.

We adopt a flexible and active approach for this strategy, which allows us to react quickly in tapping a wide universe of opportunities across 67 emerging countries. It offers a compelling investment for investors seeking emerging market debt exposure without taking on volatility associated with emerging market currencies.

Investors generally like the safe and defensive nature of this strategy, where the main risks come from sovereign credit spreads (yield differentials) and US interest rates. We currently have a positive view on the credit spreads in emerging markets. We believe the market is overpricing risks in some of the emerging market countries where we are happy to invest.
Q How will emerging markets fare this year?
A Emerging markets have generally performed well for fixed income investors over the last three years, and we think this year could offer another year of positive returns.

Continued investment inflows for the next year will give bond prices a leg-up going forward. The yield-chasing phenomenon is also expected to continue, as interest rates and bond yields globally are still low despite the rate hike cycle kicking off. However, we do not expect bond prices to rally significantly, compared to 2016 and last year. We believe emerging market hard currency bond yields have room to compress another 50 to 75 basis points, depending on the interest rate movements.

We are in an age of geopolitical risk, where the biggest sources of risks are external. We have sources of geopolitical tensions emerging which will impact emerging markets, such as the renewed instability in the Middle East and the situation with North Korea.
Risks also include continuous rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Recent noise regarding global tariff policies also warrants attention. However, not all is "gloom and doom" as some might think.

While US President Donald Trump's protectionist rhetoric raises concerns about measures against Mexico or China, emerging markets can still perform well in the event of "global reflation", given supportive macro dynamics.

For now, most emerging economies are enjoying stronger growth momentum, with solid domestic demand. In the year ahead, there is certainly room for more gains in emerging market debt, as investors have not been massively overweight on the sector.
Q What is your investment advice for the Asian investor this year?

A Investors should keep a close eye on global developments, as external challenges will play a larger role this year. This is because of the increasing importance of the economic recovery that is becoming more visible in both the US and Europe.

Investors should also look beyond the more traditional fixed-income asset class to have some exposure in emerging market debt. There is certainly room within fixed income portfolios to move away from bonds that are trading at close to zero yield. To get a meaningful yield, emerging market debt does provide investors with a large and liquid enough asset class for them to tap and get significant yield pickup.

I advise investors to have emerging market debt exposure through actively managed funds that can generate potential significant returns in relation to the market index, and avoid pitfalls by limiting exposure to more vulnerable emerging market countries.
Q What keeps you awake at night?

A I am thinking about themes that can really change our current environment and perceptions in the near future, such as climate change and advances in artificial intelligence. In the short term, increasing political tensions and rising inequality are some issues to keep in mind.
Q If I am not an investment manager, I would be...?
A An archaeologist.

Article.Art: Amundi Asset Management's Mr Sergei Strigo does not expect bond prices to rally significantly, and believes investors should look beyond the traditional fixed-income assets towards emerging market debt to get a more meaningful yield.
